messageBody:
Curt Sampson Tue Aug 26, 2003 2:04 pm
> To the extent that the next test we do is influenced by the result
> of the last test we did, we are doing exploratory testing.

> (http://www.satisfice.com/articles/what_is_et.htm)

interesting

> This seems to me that it could just as well describe test-first
> programming; I often decide what my next test will be based on the
> previous tests I've just produced. ("Hmmm. We just saw and fixed a
> failure like such-and-such, does that mean that this other thing
> might be able to fail like that, too? Let's write a test and find
> out.")

> It sounds to me like the "scripted testing" he's talking about in
> that article is not XP-style testing, where you run the tests as you
> come up with them, but instead one where you create a whole series
> of tests before you take them to the code. Especially where he says:

> Scripting has its place. I can imagine testing situations where
> efficiency and repeatability are so important that we should script
> or automate them.

> I can't imagine a situation where efficiency and repeatability are
> *not* important enough to script the tests! But if you can somehow
> manipulate the system quickly enough to do exploratory testing, you
> can probably come up with a way for the script to manipulate the
> system even more quickly, and then just add your tests to the
> script, rather than throwing them away as soon as you've tried them
> out.

s/script/suite

This is why, to me, GUI test automation based on JUnit is the way to
go:

* good tool support

* standard framework

* lotsa mindshare among coders

* tests can be refactored with code

* tests can be easily saved for regression

Michael Silverstein Tue Aug 26, 2003 3:44 pm
> The good part of ET is that you spend less time coming up with
> scripts and automating and more time testing, so you have a greater
> liklihood of going down a path you might not otherwise have tested.
> The bad part, obviously, is that because there is no automation some
> paths may only get hit once, possibly before a defect is ever
> inserted there.

And regression testing remains tedious, unless you throw your tests
back in the bucket. Why not do that? ("2 words: test maintenance" :-)

On Thu, 28 Aug 2003, Michael Silverstein wrote:
> For a better defense of ET and discussion of the limitation of
> automation than I could ever provide, you should read some of Cem
> Kaner's articles on http://www.kaner.com/. Note that I don't agree
> with a lot of it.

Michael Silverstein Thu Aug 28, 2003 7:15 pm
> To clarify my sentence above, the last word "it" equates to things
> written on the site about exploratory testing, as well as a lot of
> negatives about test automation. I already mentioned what I don't
> like about ET in my previous append and this group/XP/agile people
> can articulate the advantages of automation better than I. If you
> want to dig, Mr. Kaner and I went back and forth a bit in on this
> subject in January of this year on the software-testing group. Of
> course there's always more to be said but not enough time. Anyway,
> to reiterate a different append of mine, if you want to have a
> good/fun/heated conversation on these subjects with peple who have
> very strong, well earned opinions you should take this subject to
> the sodtware-testing group.

and for similarly insightful debate regarding GUI test automation,
consider

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/java-gui-testing/

Curt Sampson Fri Aug 29, 2003 3:50 am
> Funny, you know I am in general agreement with all he's saying about
> GUI test automation, and how it's not much use. His problem is that
> he's testing in the wrong place. He wants to test if the printer
> driver gets the margins correct, and he ends up testing the entire
> GUI, too. He's a victim of the "separate the testers and the
> programmers" method of development.

> If you replace ten difficult GUI tests with one difficult GUI test
> and ten easier tests at a lower level, suddenly you find your test
> automation has become much easier.

Yes. By all means, have a thin GUI, and test your backend, but then
automate a "real" scenario driving your GUI, to make _sure_ that the V
really goes with the M and the C the way you think it does :-) Plus,
the GUI automation is documentation, possibly even a deliverable (who
needs Flash ?-)
